cover-01.title: Active Career Management
cover-01.author: Bob Fornal
cover-01.bio1:
Entrepreneur
Code-squid provides solid, in-depth frontend training that is supported with real-world code projects. Blessed husband and proud father of two.

https://code-squid.com
cover-01.bio2:
Senior Solutions Developer
Leading EDJE, Inc.
Passionate about learning, testing, mentoring, speaking, and personal growth.

https://leadingedje.com
cover-01.notes:
Notes
  • This is a collection of thoughts and ideas.
  • You should use what works for you.
  • Some of these are best practices, some are "anti-patterns."
  • There is no guarantee of getting or maintaining a job.
  • Take and adapt what works for you.
Focus on ...
  • Entering Industry
  • Transitioning into Industry
  • Transitioning within Industry
  • Leaving Industry, Change Track

history--slide.title: History
history--slide.text1:
My History

  • 25+ Years as a Teacher (Computers)
  • 13+ Years as a Frontend Developer
  • (found) #100Devs Bootcamp
  • 700+ Coffee Chats
Over the years ...
  • "I did nothing to ACTIVELY manage my career."
history--slide.text2:
My Realization ...

  • Obligation to myself (and my family) to build a strong network.
  • What companies are good companies (by my standards)?
  • Who are the first people I will contact?
  • Am I prepared for the unexpected?
history--slide.notes:
• Throughout my career, I did EVERYTHING WRONG.
  • I started working with bootcamp students and had to figure out how to help them.
  • I had to learn more about myself.
This is a different market.
  • Developers NEED to showcase and advocate for their skills.
  • Many have never had to do this.
  • They do not understand what they NEED to do to stand out ...
  • ... employers chased them before.
Realization
  • Obligation to myself (and my family) to build a strong network.
  • What companies are good companies (by my standards)?
  • Who are the first people I will contact?
  • Am I prepared for the unexpected?

career-levels--early-career.title: Career Levels: Early-Career
career-levels--early-career.text1:
Early-Career


• Social Media

• Right Job

• Right Company

• Connections
career-levels--early-career.notes:
Breaking these down into broad scopes ...

Social Media (start to learn, professionally):
  • Conferences and Meetups
  • LinkedIn & x/Twitter (it's a tool)
  • Use #100DaysOfCode to work with the algorithm.
Right Job:
  • Goals - define
Right Company:
  • 60 Companies
  • Examine Values
Connections (build):
  • Fellow students
  • Past co-workers
  • Company peers

career-levels--mid-career.title: Career Levels: Mid-Career
career-levels--mid-career.text1:
Early-Career


• Social Media

• Right Job

• Right Company

• Connections
career-levels--mid-career.text2:
Mid-Career


• Social Media

• Right Job

• Right Company

• Connections
career-levels--mid-career.notes:
Social media (building and maintaining):
  • Conferences and Meetups
  • Maintain activity and details.
Right Job (learning):
  • Goals - actively maintain
Right Company (learn and apply):
  • 60 Companies (should have, adjust based on activity/news)
  • Actively maintain
Can be more strategic with connections ...

Connections (build and maintain):
  • Peers
  • Tech leads
  • Immediate manager
  • Past peers from school

career-levels--late-career.title: Career Levels: Late-Career
career-levels--late-career.text1:
Early-Career


• Social Media

• Right Job

• Right Company

• Connections
career-levels--late-career.text2:
Mid-Career


• Social Media

• Right Job

• Right Company

• Connections
career-levels--late-career.text3:
Late-Career


• Social Media

• Right Job

• Right Company

• Connections
career-levels--late-career.notes:
This is what prompted this talk; late career with limited understanding of Social Media ...

Social Media (different impact):
  • Conferences and Meetups (speaking and engaging)
  • Clean up and working network
Right Job:
  • Goals (are we thinging of post-retirement? I LOVE WRITING CODE)
Right Company:
  • 60 Companies
  • Actively maintain
Connections:
  • Peer Developers
  • Peer Management
  • Peers that have moved someplace else

build-things--slide.title: Building Things
build-things--slide.text1:
Issue

"Stop telling developers to make projects to get a job. I have never had an employer ask me about a project I built!"

Reality

  • This applies more to Junior than Senior.
  • Allows them to show something of significance.
  • Demonstrate proof of skill and impact.
build-things--slide.text2:
Thoughts

  • Can be used to navigate conversations.
  • Increase confidence.
  • Larger projects is where true learning occurs.
  • Stack the deck in your favor.
build-things--slide.notes:
This mentality of "not building things" comes from a mentality where demand was higher.

Projects allow you to ...
  • Show something of significance
  • Show proof of skill and impact
  • Provide talking points
  • Increase confidence
Thoughts
  • My repos are mostly small deep-dives, shows learning but not depth
  • Stack the deck in your favor
  • Talk to work on a project
Levels:
  • Early (do this)
  • Mid (do this, but how far in)
  • Late (can build - if shifting technology, but can also speak to experience)

project--slide.title: Project(s)
project--slide.text2:
Types

  • Group
  • Personal / Passion
  • Exploratory

Considerations

  • Build around what you know
  • What does a good project look like?

Killers

  • Broken Links
  • Bad Spelling
  • Grammar
project--slide.notes:
Include ...
  • Branching
  • Wiki Notes (documentation)
  • Project Board
  • PR Markdown
  • README (documentation)
  • Pipeline (live)
  • Unit Tests (tested)
  • Define and work to MVP complete.
Here are a few types of projects.
  • Group
  • Personal / Passion projects allow your care and concern to show through; this should be a solution to a problem you can speak to.
  • Exploratory
Considerations
  • Build around what you know
  • What does a good project look like?
  • KILLERS: Broken Links, Bad Spelling, and Grammar
Levels:
  • Early (need to learn these business processes)
  • Mid (don't stop doing the good business things)
  • Late (might have enough based on work experience, might not)

portfolio--slide.title: Portfolio
portfolio--slide.text1:
Sections

  • Hero (with Call To Action)
  • Images as a Dev, at Meetups
  • Projects and Tech Used
  • Resume (optional)
  • Contact Information
portfolio--slide.text2:
Considerations

  • Who are we creating this for?
  • Developers or Recruiter / Hiring Manager?
  • Are resume and links up to date?
portfolio--slide.notes:
Sections
  • Hero (with Call To Action)
  • Images as a Dev, at Meetups
  • Projects and Tech Used
  • Resume (optional)
  • Contact Information
Portfolio
  • Who are we building this for?
  • Other Devs, NO; they are references. Reach the people making a hiring decision.
  • Hero/CTA: I am the person you need on that team.
  • They need to get to know you - story/photos
Thoughts
  • Make sure you have the right focus for your portfolio.
  • Have at least two projects that you have ownership of.
  • Do you need the resume here? Especially, if you are applying for more than one type of position.
Level
  • Early (this can be a project; if not, use of templates is OK)
  • Mid (don't neglect it; redesign when in a crunch hurts)
  • Late (might need to build, if you want the exposure; build in public)

resume-ats--slide.title: Resume / ATS
resume-ats--slide.text1:
Resume

  • Summary
  • Skills
  • Employment

Considerations

  • Master Resume
  • Simpler is better (no photo, ATS ready)
  • Broken Links, Bad Spelling, and Grammar
  • Regional Differences
  • Cover Letter?
resume-ats--slide.text2:
Applicant Tracking Systems

"While we are talking about resumes ..."

Considerations

  • Track EVERYTHING
  • Applying Early
  • Opimizing Resume Content Sent
  • "The goal of the recruiter is to hire you; not to reject you." - Francesco Cuilla
resume-ats--slide.notes:
Resume
  • There are regional/cultural variances.
  • Don't lie: but a solid guess is OK.
  • Can you get numbers before leaving?
  • Summary: Why are you the best person for this job?
  • Skills: Just those listed for this job.
  • Focus bullets on what was ROI.
Cover Letter
  • If transitioning (late career counts) to explain why.
ATS
  • ATS will group by percentage match of resume to posting;
  • then, it will match by time applied - earlier and complete is the best option.
  • Track everything: Application, followups, and thank you (exquisite detail).
Level
  • This is the same at Early, Mid, and Late Career

linkedin--slide.title: LinkedIn
linkedin--slide.text1:
Sections

  • Banner
  • Image
  • Tagline
  • About - Sell yourself
  • Featured - You decide
  • Activity - weekly (minimum)
  • Experience - Industry Standard Terms
  • Skills - Endorsed
  • Recommendations
linkedin--slide.notes:
Level
  • At all levels, learn to use LI before it's needed.
  • These are common issues at all levels.
  • Sell yourself - creating an account with minimum information is bad.
Site
  • Banner needs to say, "I am in technology;" Reduce the cognitive load.
  • Image needs to be clean and bright.
  • Tagline is the first thing a recruiter sees.
  • About - Above The Fold
  • Featured: Resume, Project(s), Portfolio, Articles, Content / Posts (use an image).
  • Activity: The algorithm rewards activity (weekly MINIMUM); posts, not re-post.
  • Experience; change to Industry Standard Terms
  • Recommendations - can be considered a "red flag" if not present.
Considerations
  • Post into Groups (impact)
  • Social Saturday
Level (REPEAT)
  • At all levels, learn to use LI before it's needed.

twitter-x--slide.title: x/Twitter
twitter-x--slide.text1:
Sections

  • Banner, Image, and Tagline
  • Links
  • Pinned Post

Why?

  • Strong Tech Community
  • Recruiters / Visibility
twitter-x--slide.text2:
Patterns

  • Follow recruiters
  • Create a recruiter list
  • Retweet good content
  • Find the influencers in your industry
  • People with common interest or passion
  • People in your hometown or current location

Considerations

  • Are links correct?
twitter-x--slide.notes:
Level
  • At all levels, learn to use x/Twitter before it's needed.
  • These are common issues at all levels.
  • An active account (not rockstar) is easier to find than a brand new shiny one.
Sections
  • Banner, Image, and Tagline
  • Links (verify)
  • Pinned Post
Is there value in using x/Twitter?
  • YES; Recruiters find people here all the time
Patterns
  • Recruiters: The list helps you see what they are sharing more easily.
  • RT: People you follow will be grateful.
Patterns
  • Follow recruiters
  • Create a recruiter list
  • Retweet good content
  • Find the influencers in your industry
  • People with common interest or passion
  • People in your hometown or current location

connections--slide.title: Connections
connections--slide.text1:
LinkedIn

  • How to connect?
  • What is your ask?
  • Social Saturday?

x/Twitter

  • Strong Tech Community
  • Recruiters / Visibility
  • Strengthen Connections
connections--slide.text2:
Considerations

  • Stories - people remember the stories.
  • Active Listening
  • Validate connections in some meaningful way.
  • Use meaningful times to reconnect (Christmas).
connections--slide.notes:
LinkedIn
  • Connecting: Use the activity, become known or actively maintain.
  • What is active? Find them.
  • Use their feed ...
  • What is your ask? Connect and chat?
  • Do Social Saturdays have value?
  • Who am I supporting? Can I strengthen the connections?
x/Twitter
  • There is a string tech community
  • It increases your visibility; recruiters
Considerations
  • Stories - people remember the stories.
  • Active Listening (me taking notes)
  • Validate connections in some meaningful way.
  • Use meaningful times to reconnect (Christmas).
Levels
  • Early (reach out, make connections)
  • Mid (be active)
  • Late (continue active)

interview-types--slide.title: Interview Types
interview-types--slide.text1:
• Informal Interview
  • Cultural Fit
  • AI - Resume Overview
  • Technical - Code Challenge
  • Technical - Conversational
  • Technical - Take Home, Code Review
  • Technical - Project on Portfolio
interview-types--slide.text2:
Things to account for, research, and practice:
  • 30-second elevator pitch.
  • Company Website
  • Postings
  • Interviewer(s)
  • Tech Stack
  • Glassdoor
Plan out questions.
interview-types--slide.notes:
Types
  • Informal Interview - you initiate
  • Cultural Fit
  • AI - Resume Overview
  • Technical - Code Challenge
  • Technical - Conversational
  • Technical - Take Home, Code Review
  • Technical - Project on Portfolio
30-second elevator pitch
  • Remember that it should go beyond the resume and LinkedIn.
Company Website
  • People on LinkedIn, Products, Clients, Feedback, News, Articles, and Values.
Posting
  • What is the job? Re-read any emails. Check calendar invite.
Interviewer(s)
  • LinkedIn, Posts, Articles. STALK THEM.
Tech Stack
  • Tools, Libraries, Frameworks (anything on GitHub) - Release Notes and Related Projects.
  • Related: React & Redux, Angular & RxJS
Glassdoor
  • Interviews, About, People.
Questions
  • ALL questions that come to mind - write it down; showcase interest.
Levels
  • Early, Mid, and Late - the difference is the depth of connections

job-search--slide.title: Job Search
job-search--slide.text1:
2-Hour Job Search

  • Small/Mid-Size Companies
  • Tight Focus on Domain

Thoughts

  • Google Search Pattern
site:icims.com | greenhouse.io | jobvite.io | smartrecruiters.com | workable.com | zoho.com | myworkdayjobs.com "fullstack developer" OR "fullstack engineer" OR "full stack developer" OR "full stack engineer" AND "remote"
job-search--slide.notes:
Book - 2-Hour Job Search (Amazon)
  • Domain Specific Knowledge
  • Target a specifiv industry like Financial.
Job Search
  • Company size - large ar not safe.
  • Domain - build in that stack.
Google Seach Pattern
  • Search boards at the company level (generally more than on paid boards)
  • Adjust for job title variants
  • Remote or a specific location
  • Search within 24 hours, DAILY.
  • Target higher levels within the ATS systems.
Levels
  • Early, Mid, and Late - no difference; target activity - when you apply.

cold-calling--slide.title: Cold Calling
cold-calling--slide.text1:
Cold Emailing

  • Powerful marketing tool.
  • Effective tool for personal branding.
  • Can help you expand your search and potentially uncover new opportunities.

Challenges

  • Getting the recipient to open and read the email.
  • Crafting a message that is both compelling and personalised.
  • Personalisation is key.
  • Value proposition.
  • Make it easy to read.
cold-calling--slide.text2:
The Right People

  • Identify the ideal customer.
  • Determine their needs and what problems they face.

Mastery

  • Follow up to boost response rates.
  • Reach out through a different communication channel.
  • Balance being pushy with being persistent.
cold-calling--slide.notes:
Kind of controversial ...
  • Sales: Some people are very good at it.
  • Numbers for return/response are LOW.
  • If done right, it can be done well.
Got this from ...
  • College student reaching out to students, TAs, and professors.
  • Other colleges/companies: doing research in her field.
  • She crafted a message ... (varied), I'm doing [this] that's related
  • How can I add to that?
  • Enters the job market with a staggering network.
And, more
  • Good morning.
  • Good morning, how's it going?
  • Not just a single effort.
Cold emailing is a form of communication ...
  • Reaching out to potential employers, professors, customers, or clients
  • Who have not expressed a prior interest in a person.
Challenges
  • Capture their attention.
  • Focus on how you help them, not what YOU want from them.
  • Subject-line: Attention Grabbing (not generic)
  • Clear and concise: introduce yourself and explain why you are reaching out.
  • What can you offer?
Levels
  • Early - this is definitely something that can benefit from early use.
  • Mid - can be of benefit; need to be selective
  • Late - this can be of use if you are PLANNING a shift

networking-01--slide.title: Networking
networking-01--slide.notes:
Dilbert

Need to network in the right place.
  • Dating: There are lots of single in a bar, but probably not your best bet.
  • Conferences - ensure it's not a sales event.

networking-02--slide.title: Networking
networking-02--slide.text2:
Location

  • Network in the Right Place
  • Conferences - ensure it's not a sales event.
networking-02--slide.notes:
Thoughtful conversation
  • Get past small talk, pleasantries, and elevator pitches.
  • Have in-depth discussions about your industry, your challenges, and your goals.
Mutual benefit
  • Both parties see value in the relationship.
Respect
  • You admire each other's work and expertise.
  • There's no hidden agenda.
Networking in the right place ...
  • Compare professional networking to dating.
  • There are lots of dating opportunities in a bar; rarely partners.
  • Network where you are most comfortable - me, college not church.
(summarize top three)

Levels
  • Early - these are skills that need development; active participation.
  • Mid - these are skills you should be working on within your team.
  • Late - don't lose the momentum and experience you've built.

quickly-getting-job--slide.title: If I Had To ...
quickly-getting-job--slide.text1:
Get a Job as Quickly as Possible

  1. Referral: strong network, top 10.
  2. Domain search: targeting based on experience.
  3. Cold email: targeting and stalking.
  4. Traditional: finding jobs and applying.
quickly-getting-job--slide.text2:
Thoughts

  • They all have benefits and weaknesses.
  • They all take work, research, and persistence.
  • You need to go the route that's best for you and your circumstances.
quickly-getting-job--slide.notes:
Get a Job as Quickly as Possible
  1. Getting a job through referral: strong network, top 10 (can I list them RIGHT NOW).
  2. Domain search: targeting based on experience + google search.
  3. Cold email: targeting and stalking - only as good as the time and effort.
  4. Traditional: finding jobs and applying - this is a valid route at the right company, place, and time.
Thoughts
  • They all have benefits and weaknesses.
  • They all take work, research, and persistence.
  • You need to go the route that's best for you and your circumstances.
Levels
  • Early, Mid, Late - do these BEFORE you have the strong need, if you can.
  • All of our path(s) and requirements vary.

time-for-questions.notes:
Notes
  • This is a collection of thoughts and ideas.
  • You should use what works for you.
  1. Give Yourself a Fighting Chance (LI)
  2. Strategize: Have a Plan
  3. Sell Yourself: Why are you a good fit?
  4. Show curiosity: Question
  5. Be Authentic - be YOU, not who you think they want; bumps, bruises, and all.
Levels
  • Early, Mid, Late - do these BEFORE you have the strong need, if you can.
  • All of our path(s) and requirements vary.
